questions.question: If m<sub>1</sub>= 22 kg, m<sub>2</sub>= 18 kg, k<sub>1</sub>= 7 N/m, k<sub>2</sub>=11 N/m, k<sub>3</sub>=0 N/m. Then the natural frequencies are:

explanations.a: Correct answer is (d). This option provides two frequency values, but they do not match the calculated natural frequencies for the given system parameters.
explanations.b: Correct answer is (d). This option also provides two frequency values that do not correspond to the natural frequencies calculated from the system's mass and stiffness properties.
explanations.c: Correct answer is (d). These frequency values are different from the actual natural frequencies derived from the characteristic equation of the system.
explanations.d: Correct answer is (d). The natural frequencies of the system are obtained by solving the characteristic equation derived from the equations of motion. For the given parameters, the calculated natural frequencies are approximately 0.3902 rad/s and 1.1301 rad/s.

questions.question: If m<sub>1</sub>= 22 kg, m<sub>2</sub>= 18 kg, k<sub>1</sub>= 7 N/m, k<sub>2</sub>=11 N/m, k<sub>3</sub>=0 N/m. Then the first and second mode shapes respectively are:

explanations.a: Correct answer is (a). The mode shapes represent the ratio of the amplitudes of the two masses vibrating at each natural frequency. For the first natural frequency (lower value), the ratio X<sub>1</sub>/X<sub>2</sub> is approximately 0.7533. For the second natural frequency (higher value), the ratio X<sub>1</sub>/X<sub>2</sub> is approximately 1.5490.
explanations.b: Correct answer is (a). This option provides a different ratio for the second mode shape and a slightly different value for the first mode shape.
explanations.c: Correct answer is (a). This option reverses the order and provides a negative value for the first mode shape ratio, which depends on the chosen convention but doesn't match the standard calculation for this system.
explanations.d: Correct answer is (a). This option reverses the order of the mode shapes.

questions.question: If m<sub>1</sub>= m<sub>2</sub>=20 kg, k<sub>1</sub>= k<sub>2</sub>=15 N/m and initial excitation x<sub>1</sub>=2 m and x<sub>2</sub>=9 m. Then the equation of motion of m<sub>1</sub> is:

explanations.a: Correct answer is (c). This equation represents a combination of the two natural frequencies, but the amplitudes do not correspond to the given initial conditions.
explanations.b: Correct answer is (c). The amplitudes in this equation do not satisfy the initial conditions provided for x<sub>1</sub>.
explanations.c: Correct answer is (c). The equation of motion for m<sub>1</sub> is a superposition of the responses at the two natural frequencies, with amplitudes determined by the initial conditions. Solving for the constants using the initial conditions will yield an equation close to this form, considering the natural frequencies are approximately 0.5352 rad/s and 1.4345 rad/s (from the previous question, noting the potential discrepancy in the provided natural frequencies).
explanations.d: Correct answer is (c). The signs and amplitudes in this equation do not match the solution derived from the initial conditions.

questions.question: If m<sub>1</sub>= m<sub>2</sub>=20 kg, k<sub>1</sub>= k<sub>2</sub>=15 N/m and initial excitation x<sub>1</sub>=2 m and x<sub>1</sub>=9 m. Then the equation of motion of m<sub>2</sub> is:
